statement: Tata Motors is among the world’s leading manufacturers of ready automobiles.
The Passenger Vehicles segment grew volumes by 67%, achieving the highest ever domestic annual sales of 3,70,354 units in FY22.
Tata Motors has taken a giant leap forward in connecting the aspirations of its stakeholders by defining the future of mobility.
The Company is pioneering India’s Electric Vehicle transition and enjoys considerable advantage in one of the fastest growing automotive markets in the world.
Tata Motors has outlined its sustainability strategy and a clear roadmap of migration towards green mobility Net Zero.
The Company has maintained high standards of corporate governance and public disclosure.
The Board of Directors is committed to providing strategic direction and leadership.
The Company has successfully complied with all applicable laws and regulations to date.
The Company has a robust IT-enabled compliance management system for tracking and managing compliance.
The Company has received all necessary regulatory approvals for its operations.
The Company has reversed the initially recognised impairment for this CGU.
The Company has enhanced its market share to 8.1% for the year ended March 31, 2021 as compared to 4.8% for the year ended March 31, 2020.
The fair value of the CGU is significantly higher than its carrying value.
Despite the margins being impacted by supply chain issues and runaway commodity inflation, our India business remains in good health.
Revenue fell 7% to £18.3 billion, whilst the Company's free cash flow was negative at £1.16 billion for FY22.
Jaguar Land Rover's revenue fell by 16% in FY22 on account of supply chain issues.
The Company reported a loss of ₹11,308.76 crore for the year, compared to a loss of ₹13,395.10 crore in the previous year.
The ongoing global semiconductor shortage has significantly impacted production schedules.
The Company experienced significant losses in the financial year.
There are risks associated with instability in the market and significant currency fluctuations.
The Company may face adverse effects on trading agreements due to changes in government policies.
The Company has been subject to investigations regarding anti-competitive practices.
The Company has faced challenges related to compliance with new regulatory requirements.
The Company recorded a net loss of 11,441.47 crores for the year ended March 31, 2022.
The Company made a provision for estimated supplier claims of 114.00 crores, which were under negotiations with suppliers.
The Company recorded inventory write-down expense of 125.34 crores during the year ended March 31, 2022.
By 2025, Tata Motors will have 10 EVs in its portfolio.
60% of Jaguar Land Rover’s volumes will be pure BEV vehicles by 2030.
The Company aims to achieve net zero carbon emissions across its supply chain, products, and operations by 2039.
The EV market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 36% until 2026.
Jaguar Land Rover plans to launch a pure electric Range Rover by 2024 and five additional all-electric Land Rover models by 2026.
The Company expects to continue monitoring the impact of COVID-19 on its operations and financial condition.
The Company aims to improve its liquidity position and operational efficiency in the coming year.
The Company anticipates a gradual recovery in industry volumes as semiconductor supply improves.
The Company plans to focus on high-margin products to enhance profitability.
The Company expects to contribute 84.20 crores to the funded pension plans in the year ending March 31, 2023.
The Company anticipates that the hedged sales will take place over the next one to five years.
The ongoing shortage of semiconductors could disrupt production and delay the rollout of new vehicles.
Changes in government regulations and fiscal policies may adversely impact the Company's operations.
The Company is exposed to risks associated with product liability, warranties, and recalls.
Economic downturns and changes in consumer preferences could negatively affect demand for vehicles.
Jaguar Land Rover's operations may be significantly affected by geopolitical tensions and trade restrictions.
The Company faces risks related to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates.
There is a risk of adverse interpretations of tax laws that could impact financial results.
The Company is exposed to risks from changes in laws and regulations affecting the automotive industry.
The Company may encounter difficulties in meeting its financial obligations due to liquidity risks.
The Company faces potential penalties and legal challenges related to compliance with various regulations.
The assumptions made about the outcome of legal proceedings are subject to a high degree of uncertainty.
The Company is exposed to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates, equity prices, liquidity and credit risk.
The Company faces claims and assertions by various parties which may result in potential losses.
